> As=
saf Arkin wrote:
> > Second, NAT, your machine is most likely not
> > reach=
able from the outside world for opening new connections.
>
> What about NAT=
 traversal?  (That is admittedly a na=EFve question as I don't
> understand=
 NAT traversal but I know some apps I have used managed to work on
> my NAT=
 effectively.)

You can configure an inbound port to route to a particular =
machine, so
port 9034 on the router can route to port 80 on your machine.  =
But
that's more setup than most people can stomach, doesn't travel with
you=
 to other networks, and no easy way for the client to tell how to
reach it =
from the outside.

You can punch a hole by initiating an outbound connectio=
n from your
client to another one, which gives the other one an IP/port pai=
r they
can use to open a connection back to your client.  But it means maki=
ng
low-level calls, not something you can do with client-side JavaScript,
d=
efinitely something you can do in a browser extension.
